title: Snowdonia Adventure Weekend
tagline: Zip lines, summit hikes, and gorge scrambling in Wales' most dramatic landscape
suitableFor: Active families and groups of friends who enjoy outdoor adventures and are comfortable with moderate physical activity. Children should be at least 8 years old for most activities.
notSuitableFor: Individuals with significant mobility issues or a fear of heights. Those seeking a relaxing or luxurious getaway may find this itinerary too active.
packingEssentials: Waterproof jacket and trousers (essential - rain is common)
Hiking boots with good ankle support
Water bottle or hydration pack (2L minimum for Snowdon)
Head torch (for early starts or cave activities)
OS Map OL17 Snowdonia or GPS device
Swimsuit and quick-dry towel (for gorge walking)

stops.title: Velocity 2 Zip Line
stops.description: Experience the thrill of flying over Penrhyn Quarry on the world's fastest zip line, reaching speeds over 100mph. The experience includes a safety briefing, gear fitting, and two flights - first tandem, then solo. Book via zipworld.co.uk at least 2 weeks ahead for weekends.
stops.insiderTip: Book the first slot of the day (usually 9am) for the best chance of clear weather and shorter queues. The zip line operates in most weather conditions except high winds.

wetAlt.title: Bounce Below (Llechwedd)
wetAlt.description: Jump and explore giant trampolines suspended in a vast underground cavern - a disused Victorian slate mine. Weather-proof fun that's unique to Wales.

budgetAlt.title: Walk around Llyn Ogwen
budgetAlt.description: Free scenic walk around beautiful Llyn Ogwen with stunning views of Tryfan and the Glyderau. Easy 2-mile circuit, often less crowded than Snowdon paths.

stops.title: Pete's Eats
stops.description: THE legendary mountaineering cafe in Llanberis - a rite of passage for anyone visiting Snowdonia. Famous for enormous portions of hearty comfort food. The Pete's Big Breakfast and veggie chilli are legendary. Expect queues at weekends but the atmosphere is worth it.
stops.insiderTip: If Pete's is rammed, try Electric Mountain Cafe (5min away) or Gallt-y-Glyn for pub grub with lake views.

budgetAlt.title: Packed lunch at Llyn Padarn
budgetAlt.description: Pack sandwiches from Spar in Llanberis and enjoy with stunning lake and mountain views at one of the picnic benches.

stops.title: Llanberis Path Guided Walk
stops.description: The Llanberis Path is the longest but most gradual route to Snowdon's summit. For families or those wanting a gentler day, aim for the halfway point at the Halfway House (no longer a cafe but great viewpoint). Mountain guides available through Snowdonia Adventures or walk independently.
stops.insiderTip: Parking at Llanberis Victoria Hotel car park is cheaper than council car park. Alternatively, take the Snowdon Sherpa bus from Betws-y-Coed to avoid parking hassle.

wetAlt.title: National Slate Museum
wetAlt.description: Fascinating free museum exploring North Wales' slate mining heritage. Great for all ages with working demonstrations, historic buildings, and the longest zip line in Wales is just next door.

budgetAlt.title: Padarn Country Park Trail
budgetAlt.description: Explore the beautiful woodland and lakeside paths of Padarn Country Park. Free entry, free parking in winter. Includes views of Dolbadarn Castle.

stops.title: YHA Snowdon Llanberis
stops.description: Modern, purpose-built hostel with private rooms and dorms, right in Llanberis village. Great communal kitchen, lounge with mountain views, and friendly staff with local knowledge. Book direct via YHA for best rates.
stops.costNote: per person/night - dorms from £20, private rooms from £45
stops.insiderTip: Book a private room with mountain view if available. The hostel has a drying room - essential for wet gear.

budgetAlt.title: Jesse James Bunkhouse
budgetAlt.description: Legendary climbers' bunkhouse in Llanberis with real character. Basic but cosy, with kitchen and common room. Popular with mountaineers.

premiumAlt.title: Plas Coch Guest House
premiumAlt.description: Comfortable B&B with excellent breakfasts and mountain views. Run by outdoor enthusiasts who can offer great local tips.

stops.title: Snowdon Summit Hike (Llanberis Path)
stops.description: Early start for Snowdon summit (1085m) via the Llanberis Path - the most gradual but longest route (9 miles return). Allow 6-7 hours. The summit cafe (Hafod Eryri) is usually open 10am-4pm. Check weather via Mountain Weather Information Service (MWIS) the night before.
stops.costNote: Free if walking independently, £60-80 for guided walk
stops.insiderTip: Start by 7am to beat the crowds - Snowdon gets very busy from 10am onwards. The Llanberis Path follows the railway so you can take the train down if legs are tired (book in advance, £25 single).
stops.weatherNote: Check MWIS (mwis.org.uk) the night before. The summit can be 10°C colder than the valley with wind chill making it feel arctic even in summer.

wetAlt.title: Electric Mountain Tour
wetAlt.description: Fascinating underground tour of Dinorwig Power Station, Europe's largest pumped-storage hydroelectric scheme, built inside a mountain. Great for rainy days.

budgetAlt.title: Cwm Idwal National Nature Reserve
budgetAlt.description: Dramatic glacial cwm with easy 3-mile circular walk. Charles Darwin studied the geology here. Free entry, parking £5.

stops.title: Moel Siabod Cafe
stops.description: Welcoming cafe in Capel Curig village serving excellent homemade cakes, soups, and hot meals. Perfect refuel after a mountain day. Dog-friendly with outdoor seating.

alternative.title: Pinnacle Cafe (Capel Curig)
alternative.description: Another great option with hearty food and outdoor gear shop attached.

budgetAlt.title: Picnic at Llynnau Mymbyr
budgetAlt.description: Stunning twin lakes with iconic Snowdon views - the classic Snowdonia postcard shot. Free parking at viewpoint layby.

stops.title: Plas y Brenin National Outdoor Centre
stops.description: Wales' premier outdoor centre, run by Mountain Training. Modern rooms, excellent restaurant, bar, and climbing wall. Perfect base for serious adventurers. Non-residents can use the bar and cafe.
stops.insiderTip: Book dinner in the restaurant - quality is excellent and you won't want to drive out. The bar often has live music on weekends.

budgetAlt.title: Bryn Gwynant YHA
budgetAlt.description: Beautiful Victorian mansion hostel in stunning lakeside location between Capel Curig and Beddgelert. One of the most scenic hostels in the UK.

stops.title: Gorge Walking Adventure
stops.description: Scramble up a river gorge, climb waterfalls, slide down natural water chutes, and jump into plunge pools. All equipment provided including wetsuit, helmet, and buoyancy aid. Sessions run near Bala with experienced instructors. Book minimum 48hrs in advance.
stops.insiderTip: Gorge walking is MORE fun in light rain - the waterfalls are bigger! Sessions rarely cancelled unless river levels are dangerously high.

wetAlt.title: National White Water Centre (Spectator)
wetAlt.description: Watch the rafting action from the riverside cafe. Free to watch, plus you can book a last-minute rafting session if inspired (from £52/hr).

budgetAlt.title: Bala Lake Walk
budgetAlt.description: Peaceful 9-mile walk around Wales' largest natural lake (Llyn Tegid). Can take the narrow gauge railway one way. Railway: £8 adult.

stops.title: The White Lion Royal Hotel
stops.description: Historic coaching inn in the heart of Bala serving excellent pub food and local Welsh ales. Warm welcome, hearty portions. Good vegetarian options.

alternative.title: Plas yn Dre
alternative.description: Traditional Welsh restaurant with local produce. Slightly upmarket.

budgetAlt.title: Bala Lake Cafe
budgetAlt.description: Simple lakeside cafe with sandwiches, hot drinks, and ice cream. Outdoor seating with views.

standard.notes: Based on 2 adults sharing, mid-range options, own transport

budget.notes: Hostels, packed lunches, one paid activity, budget alternatives

premium.notes: Guided activities, B&B accommodation, restaurant meals

knowBeforeYouGo.weather: Snowdonia's weather is notoriously unpredictable - it can rain 200+ days per year. Always check MWIS (Mountain Weather Information Service) the night before mountain activities. Pack waterproofs even on sunny forecasts. Summit temperature is typically 10°C lower than valleys.
knowBeforeYouGo.traffic: The A5 through Snowdonia gets very congested on sunny weekends. Allow 30% extra travel time in peak season. Pen-y-Pass car park fills by 7am on summer weekends - use Sherpa buses from Llanberis instead. Parking apps: PayByPhone widely accepted.
knowBeforeYouGo.booking: Zip World activities sell out weeks in advance for weekends - book as early as possible (up to 6 months ahead). Gorge walking needs minimum 48hr notice. Accommodation in Llanberis books up fast for summer weekends.
knowBeforeYouGo.fitness: This itinerary requires moderate fitness. Snowdon via Llanberis is challenging (9 miles, 950m elevation gain). Gorge walking involves swimming, scrambling, and some jumping. Most activities need to be comfortable walking on uneven ground for 2+ hours.
knowBeforeYouGo.mobileSignal: Mobile signal is patchy in the mountains. Download offline maps (OS Maps app or Google Maps). Tell someone your plans before heading to remote areas.
knowBeforeYouGo.sherpaService: The Snowdon Sherpa bus service runs year-round connecting key locations without a car: Bangor, Llanberis, Pen-y-Pass, Nant Peris. £2 per ride, day ticket £5. Very useful for linear walks.

addDay.title: Add White Water Rafting
addDay.description: Extend your trip with a morning at the National White Water Centre on the River Tryweryn. Class 3-4 rapids, suitable for beginners with good fitness.

alternative.title: Via Ferrata at Zip World
alternative.description: Swap the Snowdon hike for a Via Ferrata adventure - scaling the quarry walls on metal rungs and wire bridges. Thrilling but less demanding than a full mountain day.
